thread.title: 'Yelling and whimpering' heard as five people injured in late-night Whangarei shooting
thread.title_full: 'Yelling and whimpering' heard as five people injured in late-night Whangarei shooting

title: 'Yelling and whimpering' heard as five people injured in late-night Whangarei shooting
text:
'Yelling and whimpering' heard as five people injured in late-night Whangarei shooting Last updated 10:43, February 23 2017 DANICA MACLEAN/FAIRFAX NZ 
A scene guard was in place at the address overnight, on Clark Rd in Whangarei. 
Residents of a Whangarei street heard people "yelling and whimpering" around the time of a shooting that left five people seriously injured on Wednesday night. 
Do you know anything more? Send your newstips to 
Police were called to an address on Clark Rd in the suburb of Kamo around 10.30pm. DANICA MACLEAN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Police tape surrounds a property at the centre of a shooting on Clark Rd in Whangarei on Wednesday night. 
Neighbours said there had been a lot of commotion at the address. They did not want to be named, for fear of backlash from the people who lived there. 
READ MORE: 
The incident was believed to be gang-related, with nearby residents saying it was not the first time there had been an argument at the house. RNZ 
Five people with gunshot wounds have had surgery after a shooting in Whangarei last night. Lois Williams is at the scene and says it is a quiet family street and the house in question is a rental property with what neighbours describe as a lot of "comings and goings" 
One described it as "a bit of row" and said he heard car doors opening and shutting and cars taking off up the road. 
Another said he heard "a guy yelling and whimpering". 
A third said there was a banging noise and people were wandering up and down the street. 
The residents said a "commotion" went on for several hours on Wednesday evening. 
They didn't hear any distinguishable gun shots. 
"I thought maybe they were having a scrap," said another resident. 
Clark Rd is a quiet Kamo street, home to many older residents, and not far from local schools. 
Residents have called police in the past, as people associated with the house have been "hooning" up and down the road. 
One Clark Rd resident said there was frequently excessive noise from the rented property. 
"There are lots of comings and goings." 
Residents didn't seeing any ambulances arrive at the property, but did see a taxi. 
One resident said she had not seen any gang insignia at the property recently, but had seen some there before Christmas. 
A worker at a nearby Mobil station said locals had said there was fighting in the area, and people shooting from cars. 
SURGERY FOR VICTIMS 
All five victims suffered serious gun-related injuries, and were taken to Whangarei Hospital. 
Three of them had surgery overnight, while another was awaiting surgery. 
The fifth person was flown to Auckland Hospital and was undergoing surgery there. 
Whangarei mayor Sheryl Mai said she was dismayed to hear the "terrible news". 
"We feel for the families, friends and community of the people caught up in this," she said. 
It is not yet clear whether the shootings were the work of a lone gunman. 
A police spokesperson said police could not say whether a gunman was still on the loose, and could not guarantee there was not further risk to public safety. 
"Obviously we can't make that kind of guarantee," she said. 
"Police are investigating the incident and are already speaking with people involved," said Detective Senior Sergeant Dene Begbie. 
"A scene guard has been in place overnight and an examination will be carried out today." 
Whangarei has seen a spate of shootings recently that have involved gang members. 
John Henry Harris, 37, known as John Boy, died on October 18 last year from a gunshot wound to his chest. 
He was dropped off in a critical condition on the doorstep of a local ambulance station. 
Police later released pictures of gang members taken moments before the shooting in an attempt to find who killed him. 
There have been growing concerns about an increase in gang violence which seems to be linked to the nationwide meth market. 
Anyone who may have seen anything in the area of the Wednesday night shooting is asked to contact Whangarei police on 09 430 4500. 
Alternatively, they can call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111. - Stuff
